Ah, Final Fantasy Tactics, one of my favorite games of all time and one of my favorite stories in gaming. I was excited for this remake but I wasn't sure like...HOW excited? I wasn't sure if I'd drop everything to play a game i've played a bunch but the changes really made this feel like I was playing it for the first time again. I'm gonna try to avoid spoilers and break down what I think is good, what I think is a miss, and what I think is just ok and what makes this version worth playing over the others.

General thoughts before I get into the pros/cons:
This is a beautiful game about the corruption of those in power and of privilege. An important game with an important reminder that kindness does prevail in the face of evil, even if it takes a long time.

Lets start with the big improvements,  the UI and controls are huge quality of life improvements, just makes the game more fun and easier for new players to understand.  Just a flat improvement there.

The biggest improvement for me though? The voice acting. I'll be honest I kinda slept on it, I didn't think too much of it despite the VO for Tactice Ogre: Reborn also making that game great but the performances in this game KILL it, I have felt feelings I have never felt before in my other playthroughs, I'm a bit astounded by how much it truly adds to the experience even as someone who doesn't really have a preference in the text vs VO debate. 

Another small new thing is that many characters now have additional dialog, some of which is *extremely* good, adding a lot of character, I just really don't understand the decision to not put the WotL stuff in this, it makes the package feel incomplete and I miss the expanded sections with Delita and a few other sidequests the lack of the wotl content is the only major thing that keeps me from calling this a nearly perfect release.

A lot of characters, namely Cloud, have gotten buffed or adjusted significantly it makes everyone feel more fun to use and therefore more variety in playthroughs!  

One other thing that I kinda wish was different: this game has the beautiful cutscenes from WotL with the new awesome dub, thats great, but they are tucked in the chronicle menu, I wish they either played automatically or had an option for the player to decide which version of scenes they'd rather see, perhaps a mod will come along that will auto-play the cutscenes. 



Finished 100% all achievements, honestly the jp gain could probably still be increased further especially as this game has no endgame the grind to max out all jobs is kinda taxing.

I have a huge amount of nostalgia for playing the original game back on the PlayStation 1, and I've long been hoping for a PC remaster. I'm delighted to say that this has not disappointed at all. In addition to being a wonderful nostalgia trip for me, this is just solidly a really great game and a great remaster of it. The story, the characters, the atmosphere, and the music all come together to make this game a really special experience. I loved it when I was younger, and revisiting it now and being able to appreciate more of the nuance in the story is really rewarding. It's a story that still has an alarming amount of relevance today. And the soundtrack is probably one of my personal favourites of any game.

As remasters go, it's lovely - it doesn't overdo anything, just sharpens and gives some quality of life improvements to the graphics and interface, but not so much that it feels like a different game or like it's been overly tampered with. If you grew up with the PS1 version, there's the option to play it in 'classic mode' but even playing in the new remastered mode will still feel perfectly familiar. The biggest functional change is that it's now fully voice-acted (which again, you can avoid through 'classic mode' if you wish), and personally I think they've done a superb job of it. The acting feels natural yet passionate. The entire game is a beautiful journey that manages to be a classic Final Fantasy sword and sorcery adventure, while venturing through political intrigue, class warfare, and philosophy. For all these heavy topics it takes itself appropriately seriously to be a hard-hitting high fantasy, but without taking it to a 'Game of Thrones' style excess. It makes you care, but keeps it fun.

I love this game. I think they've done a great job in bringing it back, and I'm so glad they finally have. I hope you'll love it too.

Final Fantasy Tactics Ivalice brings back the feeling of playing the original PlayStation classic. Some aspects clearly show their age, but that is part of its charm. Revisiting the maps, the music, and the old battle flow feels like opening a time capsule of a very distinct era of tactical RPGs. For anyone who once spent countless hours with the original, this version provides a faithful and nostalgic return to Ivalice.

I've always referred to FFT as one of my all-time favourite games, and replaying it through The Ivalice Chronicles has definitely solidified its place in my top 3. The music is as brilliant as I remember and I'm much more appreciative of the writing now than when I played the original (at the wee age of ten, mind you). [b]Should old fans pick this one up? Yes! Here's why:[/b]
+ The English voice acting is pretty good! Especially Delita imo, and Argath's VA knows exactly how to make you hate him. My 10yo self didn't read the original game text in British but my adult self finds their use of posh accents for the nobility and rougher accents for commoners to be a rather nice touch.
+ The roster menu has a built-in job unlock tree that shows you all the requirements for each class, which is a very welcome QoL update. (I don't recall the original PS1 game having it but forgive me if I'm mistaken.)
+ The speed button, by the gods the [b]speed button[/b]‚Äîan amazing QoL update. As someone that played the original on a PS1 with an ever-diminishing attention span, it's all I'd ever ask for in a remaster.

[b]Should you become a new fan? Yes! Here's why:[/b]
+ The writing is brilliant! The story is compelling and timeless, and the tonal consistency really does wonders for pulling you into its vibrant world. Also enhancing it is the prominent use of leitmotif, allowing this story to be a feast for eyes and ears both, which leads me to...
+ The music! The soundtrack does an excellent job of framing the story and setting the mood‚Äîso much so that I still remember many of the tunes 20+ years later. The woodwinds are beautifully calming, the strings are haunting, the French horns are bold, and the chiming of the bells is otherworldly. I'd describe this orchestral masterpiece of a soundtrack as simply [i]transcendent[/i].
+ The gameplay is unlike any other turn-based tactical RPG I've played. Each character can change to any job (or class), which drives the primary combat abilities available to that character. After learning abilities from other jobs, you can mix and match combat abilities as well as reaction/support/movement abilities from other classes. A mage that's mastered both black and white magicks? Sure! A bulkily armoured knight given thiefly movement and abilities? Why not? A samurai that can nag your enemies until they join you? Hell yeah. What results is that each of your roster feels like they have their own unique identity that you're building them toward, which gives life to even the generic (non-unique/non-story) characters that still chose to dedicate their lives to your cause.

I also love all the little esoteric 1997 game design choices -- this game has a stat named Bravery that has some useful functions, such as dictating the chance that your passive abilities will trigger on reaction, but also, if it descends below a certain threshold your unit will become a chicken and desert the party forever. Likewise, if a unit becomes too Faithful, they'll also leave the party, having grown too pious for the battlefield. The early game tends to descend into a party of squires throwing rocks at each other for incidental XP and there's a set of formulas dictating which units are most compatible w/ one another based on their zodiac sign. This is all weird, tasty stuff in my book. I hadn't played this one before and in acquainting myself with the body of FFT academia on GameFAQs, Reddit, etc. it became so tangibly clear to me how people have eschewed so many other video games to just replay this bad boy ad nauseam.

It's maybe a little one-note with its wordy highborn medieval turns of phrase but the script is fantastically written and its themes have aged tremendously well. Maybe it also gets lost slightly when the party is fighting arcane demons brought forth from ancient magic stones, but its explorations of class, society, royalty, religion, family, etc. are all pretty well articulated. I still need to check a few of them off the list, but I think it's fair to claim that not many other Final Fantasy games have this much to say. 

This version is also the cleanest that this game's ever been presented. Its diorama-esque maps look great, it's been rebalanced slightly (but not to the extent that the flavorful 1997 jank has been tuned out), and it's got voice acting this time. And it's good! Everyone really does the Old English justice. And there's an encyclopedia in there! It's got lore, maps, character biographies, and every game mechanic meticulously explained. For everything else, consult GameFAQs, those guys have been playing this game for 28 years and many of their online dissertations apply just as readily to this version as well. Their love for this game is well founded.

There are two kinds of people. The first kind asks "50 dollars for a 30 year old game? No new content? PSP content not included? Why would I buy this?"
The second asks "A new release of potentially the best game ever made, with significant improvements, new story content. and a "hard" mode that gives more of the obscure classes space to shine?" and doesn't really look at the price.

This is finally, after 30 years, a definitive version of a masterpiece. The first version to come out with no significant bugs since the original psx release, and the first version to come out in the US with the Sound Novels intact. These may just be light novel CYOA side-stories, but they are significant pieces of world-building which enrich Ivalice far more than the minor changes to dialogue here and there.

The changes to poaching make it a far more satisfying system. Tactician mode, while it doesn't sound like a big change to the game on paper, makes it feel significantly more satisfying to play.

Some people loved the War of the Lions content. They like to have more things. Fair enough. But the new characters, the new fights, and the new classes significantly cheapened the world building. They were like the comic book version of The Prisoner -- superfluous, thoughtless fluff tacked on to a complete and well-realized piece of art to make a quick buck at the expense of the artist.

When you look at preserving one of the only games ever made that could be considered art, you want to respect the holistic experience of new people coming in and enjoying it for the first time. You cut it to the bone, and you sharpen what's left -- that's the way of art.

The way of games may be to Katamari everything you have into a gacha-ready sphere, but by NOT doing that, Matsuno and Square have made a statement about how much they respect you as an audience. 

They respect that you wouldn't just see Luso appear in Ivalice and think "cool character me get". but that questions would occur to you about who this child is, where he comes from, and why he would sacrifice his life to war. They respect that if you saw Algus brought back to life you wouldn't be pleased to kill him again, but terrified at the prospect that all of the battles Heroes fight will come to naught against the vain art of the necromancer.

They respect that you can look at Gaffgarion and know for a fact that he did not take 8 levels in black mage.

Like finding a copy of 100 years of solitude or T.S. Eliot's poems in the 50 cent bin at a used book store, buying this is an absolute no-brainer if you don't already own a copy.

The zodiac system adds random percentage to hit or miss baked into every character. The details of this system are buried under menus, are not clearly explained to the character, and overall have too much effect. 50% reduced accuracy for a bad zodiac, something you can't change, and is just inherent, is terrible design in my opinion. There is a reason you don't see it in future games.

The magic system fires after a delay of several turns, and white magic can miss your own characters. The delay of magic makes them unreliable, as enemies can move out of a targeted area, or if directly targeted, move next to a friendly unit, maybe hitting them as well. White magic is subject to accuracy. With the previously mentioned zodiac system, you can have sub 50% accuracy for healing or revival spells. Both these mechanics are frustrating, and there is a reason you don't see them in future games.

All xp in this game is tied to actions taken during turns. All abilities for classes are available from the start of the game, and cost xp. This is a plus for some people, It is a deep negative for me. This system encourages minmax behavior which is efficient but inherently unfun. Behaviors like farming single maps for hours with repeatable healing spells or buffs to farm xp until a class is maxed. Future games award job xp for completing maps, and individual abilities are tied to equipment, the introduction of which paces out class progression throughout the game. There is a reason this was changed in future games.

Creating new teammates to resolve the above issues is also very punishing, as all new characters start at level one with no catchup mechanics. New characters will always be however many hours of progression behind your other characters. They change this in future games.

As someone new to this game; Who did not know about zodiac until 15 hours into the game. Who chose several magic users. Who spent several hours grinding abilities, just to have essentially bricked characters because of their poor zodiac alignments; This game pisses me off.

Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles takes place chronologically after the events of Final Fantasy XII, with a war ravaged Ivalice in the midst of rising political unrest. The protagonist, Ramza Beoulve, is a squire to one of the main military families which rules over the region, and largely naive to the abuse the common folk have endured. Accompanied by his friend Delita, the two set off on a quest to save Ramza's sister, who is kidnapped as part of a political move by a rival faction. Unfortunately, these events end in tragedy, which lead to Ramza abandoning his house, and becoming entangled in The War of the Lions, a battle for power over the throne.

Clearly inspired by The War of the Roses, much of the story involves Ramza's experiences with oppressed common folk, who resent nobility for their over taxation, and cruel treatment. The story begins to pivot towards a more Final Fantasy direction when it becomes known that twelve mysterious "Zodiac Crystals" contain immense power, which could turn the war in the favor of whomever possesses them. Ramza, having witnessed the inhumane danger these crystals possess, thus rallies a band of allies to his cause to stop them from being used for evil. 

The dialogue presents a nice backdrop of political intrigue along with interpersonal conflicts between Ramza's idealism and the oppressed citizens. While I enjoyed the writing for the first two chapters, I felt it became significantly less interesting after Chapter III, particularly as the cast grew ever larger in size, and it became difficult to keep track of characters who appear for all of one or two scenes only to be assassinated less than an hour later. The seiyuu do a good job with their roles, though many feel type cast at this point for work they've done in anime. Nevertheless, if one does have a chance to play, I'd suggest the JP language. For those who speak Japanese, they'll also pick up on some subtle differences in the way the scripts were written in Japanese, compared to how they were translated into English. Yet again another confusing instance of Square Enix inconsistently translating their scripts.


Ramza commands a crew of mercenaries who start as standard Final Fantasy based job archetypes. Each job performs differently in battle, with Knights having large health pools and greater physical damage, whereas Black Mages specialize in magical attacks from afar. As characters gain "job experience" they can unlock additional abilities from their job skill tree. Characters can have an active job and a passive job, meaning they can mix skills from multiple job trees to create a spell slinging Monk, or a heavy armor wearing Ninja. 

Combat takes place in mission format combat encounters across a relatively small field of combat, heavily relying upon verticality to create diverse combat encounters atop roof tops, or within swamps. Nearly all the RPG knowledge one has from other Final Fantasy games translate to tactics, with spells like Reflect preventing magic from being cast on a character, and all the common status effects being present. Frustratingly the missions in Final Fantasy Tactics feel incredibly one note, with very little variety on the objectives, other than just "kill this person" or "kill all these people," which limits the utility of a number of the Jobs.

Unfortunately, I found there to be many issues with Final Fantasy Tactics. The game did not feel like it was paced correctly for its story relative to the job and level experiences expected of the player. Leveling up feels meaningless because players can do it by literally just standing on a map and talking to themselves for an hour. Basically, characters gain experience for their level and job experience for their job by "doing things" during a mission. While this could mean attacking enemies or healing allies, it can also be accomplished by tasks which have no resource limit component, such as the Squire ability Focus. A player could start a random encounter and end it instantly, or they could sit there and just gain free levels until level 99. There are many other tactical RPGs I've played where this is addressed by carefully balancing main story encounters with optional missions, making the whole RPG growth aspect feel rather lazy.

Leveling up characters feels even more useless when Act IV comes around, and suddenly everyone and their grandmother decides they want to join your party, and all are unique characters. Final Fantasy Tactics has a bizarre method of recruiting allies, which seems to pin their level to the highest party member on your team at the time of recruitment. In practice, this meant that everyone who joined my party towards the end of the game were not only wildly stronger than my original party, but also came with absurd unique skills making them hard to pass up on a team. 

Final Fantasy Tactics does not feel tactical, as building a good party is basically pointless, and the "solution" to every combat encounter seemed to just be to use a character with Arithmeticks. It was such a frustratingly hollow experience when I reached the final boss, and realized there was no point bringing any of my initial companions who I'd spend dozens of hours training, when this dragon I recruited on a whim on the last mission did 999 guaranteed damage, and using a companion ability, I could double that before the boss even got a turn. It just felt... bad, like nothing I'd done in the game mattered by the end.

While Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles is praiseworthy for its production value as a tactical RPG, there are many aspects which I did not mesh well with. For me, this would not necessarily be something I'd be quick to recommend to others, even fans of the tactical RPG genre. However, I did still enjoy my time with it, even though I find it silly that a mission involving chocobos was harder than the final boss for me.

- Targeting & accuracy pop-up before every enemy action, with no toggle to turn it off, and need to press confirm to skip through it rather than waiting.  It isn't some quick thing, it adds two seconds to each AI attack.
- Fast forward only when holding down a button, with no toggle, or setting for what multiplier it should be.
- Resets auto-advance on every cutscene, including simple scene transitions.
- Dithering filter is fine as a default, but what people want will differ greatly on screen size and circumstance.  I really notice it on my OLED monitor, but on LED TV I think it is fine and think it contributes to the CRT feel they went with for the sprite upscaling.
- No camera speed option, or settings for when it rotates.  It just leads to extra pauses as the camera rotates before an action plays out.
- No ability to move when in the overhead tactical view.  Why?  A lot of the camera stuff are solved problems.
- No scene skip option, instead the player has to just hold down R1 to speed things along.

Still, there's not really any argument to be made for people to play the older versions of FFT.  The lack of move cancel, lack of auto save, and absolutely bullshit random encounters will probably get 80% of people to give up on the game, and then the point of no return brick points would finish off a decent chunk of the rest.   They really did fix a ton of critical problems in this recreation of the game, but there's still some obvious work that should be done before I can recommend it to a 2025 audience.

I loved Tactics Advance as a kid, and appreciate the customizability compared to a game like Fire Emblem. However three specific things make me kind of hate Tactics. The zodiac system, the magic system, and the overall design of class progression.

There is a reason you don't see it in future games.

The magic system fires after a delay of several turns, and white magic can miss your own characters. The delay of magic makes them unreliable, as enemies can move out of a targeted area, or if directly targeted, move next to a friendly unit, maybe hitting them as well. White magic is subject to accuracy. With the previously mentioned zodiac system, you can have sub 50% accuracy for healing or revival spells. Both these mechanics are frustrating, and there is a reason you don't see them in future games.

All xp in this game is tied to actions taken during turns. All abilities for classes are available from the start of the game, and cost xp. This is a plus for some people, It is a deep negative for me. This system encourages minmax behavior which is efficient but inherently unfun. Behaviors like farming single maps for hours with repeatable healing spells or buffs to farm xp until a class is maxed. Future games award job xp for completing maps, and individual abilities are tied to equipment, the introduction of which paces out class progression throughout the game. There is a reason this was changed in future games.

Creating new teammates to resolve the above issues is also very punishing, as all new characters start at level one with no catchup mechanics. New characters will always be however many hours of progression behind your other characters. They change this in future games.

Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles takes place chronologically after the events of Final Fantasy XII, with a war ravaged Ivalice in the midst of rising political unrest. The protagonist, Ramza Beoulve, is a squire to one of the main military families which rules over the region, and largely naive to the abuse the common folk have endured. Accompanied by his friend Delita, the two set off on a quest to save Ramza's sister, who is kidnapped as part of a political move by a rival faction. Unfortunately, these events end in tragedy, which lead to Ramza abandoning his house, and becoming entangled in The War of the Lions, a battle for power over the throne.

Clearly inspired by The War of the Roses, much of the story involves Ramza's experiences with oppressed common folk, who resent nobility for their over taxation, and cruel treatment. The story begins to pivot towards a more Final Fantasy direction when it becomes known that twelve mysterious "Zodiac Crystals" contain immense power, which could turn the war in the favor of whomever possesses them. Ramza, having witnessed the inhumane danger these crystals possess, thus rallies a band of allies to his cause to stop them from being used for evil. 

The dialogue presents a nice backdrop of political intrigue along with interpersonal conflicts between Ramza's idealism and the oppressed citizens. While I enjoyed the writing for the first two chapters, I felt it became significantly less interesting after Chapter III, particularly as the cast grew ever larger in size, and it became difficult to keep track of characters who appear for all of one or two scenes only to be assassinated less than an hour later. The seiyuu do a good job with their roles, though many feel type cast at this point for work they've done in anime. Nevertheless, if one does have a chance to play, I'd suggest the JP language. For those who speak Japanese, they'll also pick up on some subtle differences in the way the scripts were written in Japanese, compared to how they were translated into English. Yet again another confusing instance of Square Enix inconsistently translating their scripts.


Ramza commands a crew of mercenaries who start as standard Final Fantasy based job archetypes. Each job performs differently in battle, with Knights having large health pools and greater physical damage, whereas Black Mages specialize in magical attacks from afar. As characters gain "job experience" they can unlock additional abilities from their job skill tree. Characters can have an active job and a passive job, meaning they can mix skills from multiple job trees to create a spell slinging Monk, or a heavy armor wearing Ninja. 

Combat takes place in mission format combat encounters across a relatively small field of combat, heavily relying upon verticality to create diverse combat encounters atop roof tops, or within swamps. Nearly all the RPG knowledge one has from other Final Fantasy games translate to tactics, with spells like Reflect preventing magic from being cast on a character, and all the common status effects being present. Frustratingly the missions in Final Fantasy Tactics feel incredibly one note, with very little variety on the objectives, other than just "kill this person" or "kill all these people," which limits the utility of a number of the Jobs.

Unfortunately, I found there to be many issues with Final Fantasy Tactics. The game did not feel like it was paced correctly for its story relative to the job and level experiences expected of the player. Leveling up feels meaningless because players can do it by literally just standing on a map and talking to themselves for an hour. Basically, characters gain experience for their level and job experience for their job by "doing things" during a mission. While this could mean attacking enemies or healing allies, it can also be accomplished by tasks which have no resource limit component, such as the Squire ability Focus. A player could start a random encounter and end it instantly, or they could sit there and just gain free levels until level 99. There are many other tactical RPGs I've played where this is addressed by carefully balancing main story encounters with optional missions, making the whole RPG growth aspect feel rather lazy.

Leveling up characters feels even more useless when Act IV comes around, and suddenly everyone and their grandmother decides they want to join your party, and all are unique characters. Final Fantasy Tactics has a bizarre method of recruiting allies, which seems to pin their level to the highest party member on your team at the time of recruitment. In practice, this meant that everyone who joined my party towards the end of the game were not only wildly stronger than my original party, but also came with absurd unique skills making them hard to pass up on a team. 

Final Fantasy Tactics does not feel tactical, as building a good party is basically pointless, and the "solution" to every combat encounter seemed to just be to use a character with Arithmeticks. It was such a frustratingly hollow experience when I reached the final boss, and realized there was no point bringing any of my initial companions who I'd spend dozens of hours training, when this dragon I recruited on a whim on the last mission did 999 guaranteed damage, and using a companion ability, I could double that before the boss even got a turn. It just felt... bad, like nothing I'd done in the game mattered by the end.

While Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles is praiseworthy for its production value as a tactical RPG, there are many aspects which I did not mesh well with. For me, this would not necessarily be something I'd be quick to recommend to others, even fans of the tactical RPG genre. However, I did still enjoy my time with it, even though I find it silly that a mission involving chocobos was harder than the final boss for me.

Among the most galling parts is how little of the content is new here.  Like Bethesda and Blizzard, they're taking a game that was good and porting it to modern formats while doing the bare minimum to make the game compatible.  So, they can just sell you the same game over and over and float on the nostalgia instead of making something new or even doing so much as a good mod group to add to the game.  It's lazy and the price you pay ought to reflect that.  If you played this before, buy it on sale after they put back all the content they've held back to get the nostalgia fix you crave. It is one of the greatest turn-based RPGs ever made, with a powerful political storyline that was making betrayal and intrigue cool long before Game of Thrones. The job based progression is almost flawless and rewards experimentation and grinding with the ability to cobble together skillsets and passive abilities from across jobs/classes.

The voice acting is pretty good so far. I do like it, and it adds some emotional resonance to the story sequences. I do not like the talking heads in the chat boxes while they are speaking; these look cheap and unexpressive. 

The QoL is far less than I expected and outside of the ability to change difficulties anytime I don't know that I've seen anything impressive in that area.

The sprites look far better in screenshots than in 1440p. They aren't bad, but the psuedo-retro, partially polished, just feels like someone put a screening layer over them as opposed to really improving them. After seeing the work in the 2.5 HD games I really expected these to be better looking and they aren't. They aren't bad as far as retro games go, but paying a full premium for the game I expected some real investment into the graphics and this falls flat to me. 

Hopefully the modding community can come up with some really cool injections of functionality and sprites. In the meantime, I'm going to play through and enjoy the game, but want people to come into it eyes wide open.

The best version of a great game, but still needs a UI overhaul and a bunch of options that are typically in the UIs of newly created RPGs.  You shouldn't have to press a button to skip the obnoxious UI popup before every enemy attack, or hold down a button for a game speed up.

There's just a whole bunch of little UI things that bother me, enough to bring up.  I appreciate them doing this sort of ground-up rebuild/recode of the entire game engine, but so much of it defies standard UI and option practices.  

- Targeting & accuracy pop-up before every enemy action, with no toggle to turn it off, and need to press confirm to skip through it rather than waiting.  It isn't some quick thing, it adds two seconds to each AI attack.
- Fast forward only when holding down a button, with no toggle, or setting for what multiplier it should be.
- Resets auto-advance on every cutscene, including simple scene transitions.
- Dithering filter is fine as a default, but what people want will differ greatly on screen size and circumstance.  I really notice it on my OLED monitor, but on LED TV I think it is fine and think it contributes to the CRT feel they went with for the sprite upscaling.
- No camera speed option, or settings for when it rotates.  It just leads to extra pauses as the camera rotates before an action plays out.
- No ability to move when in the overhead tactical view.  Why?  A lot of the camera stuff are solved problems.
- No scene skip option, instead the player has to just hold down R1 to speed things along.

The good news is that since this isn't just some assembly code port, these are all fixable. The bad news is that I have no idea on whether the developers genuinely care about any of these things.  Still, there's not really any argument to be made for people to play the older versions of FFT.  The lack of move cancel, lack of auto save, and absolutely bullshit random encounters will probably get 80% of people to give up on the game, and then the point of no return brick points would finish off a decent chunk of the rest.   They really did fix a ton of critical problems in this recreation of the game, but there's still some obvious work that should be done before I can recommend it to a 2025 audience.
